text: WASHINGTON — Republican senators on Wednesday released the names of some Obama administration officials who made requests during the presidential transition to see fuller versions of classified intelligence reports, immediately prompting accusations that President Trump’s allies were wielding the information for his political benefit.

headline: M.I.T. Closes ‘Food Computer’ Project After Scientists Raised Doubts
text: A high-profile research project at M.I.T.’s Media Lab that promoted growing food at home in mini-greenhouses was quietly closed last month amid allegations that its results were exaggerated to sponsors and the public, the university confirmed this week.

headline: The Electoral College Is a Confusing Mess
text: The workings of the Electoral College — our hopelessly arcane and antidemocratic way of picking the president — have come before the Supreme Court only a handful of times since the founding.

headline: America’s True Covid Toll Already Exceeds 100,000
text: Many supporters of President Trump believe that the figures for coronavirus fatalities are inflated, and Trump himself shared a tweet doubting the accuracy of some virus figures.

headline: Trump Picks Ex-Drug Company Executive to Lead Accelerated Coronavirus Vaccine Effort
text: WASHINGTON — President Trump has picked a former executive of a major pharmaceutical company to lead Operation Warp Speed, the government’s effort to speed up development of a vaccine for the coronavirus, a senior administration official said Wednesday.

headline: Pick Your Favorite Anxiety
text: Whenever Donald Trump appears in public, you can be sure of a couple of things: He will not wear a mask, and he will brag about having beaten back Chinese travelers.

headline: Mexico Covid Map and Case Count
text: A detailed map shows the extent of the coronavirus outbreak, with charts and tables of the number of cases and deaths.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
text: Americans seem to be running out of patience with fighting the coronavirus by staying home.

headline: Judge in Flynn Case Renowned for His Independent Streak
text: WASHINGTON — Federal prosecutors had scored a stunning victory in 2008 with the successful conviction on corruption charges of Senator Ted Stevens of Alaska, a powerful Republican, when months later they were astonished as Judge Emmet G. Sullivan turned the tables on them.

headline: Keeping a Distance, From Everything but Nature
text: New York, we know, is a city of interiors — the museums and the concert halls, the word-of-mouth restaurants and the pheromone-fogged bars. Those places have been unavailable for months now and are likely to stay that way for months more. To protect ourselves and others, we have been asked to remain in our homes, interiors that excite almost no one.

headline: Trump Pointedly Criticizes Fauci for His Testimony to Congress
text: WASHINGTON — President Trump on Wednesday criticized congressional testimony delivered a day earlier by Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, the nation’s top infectious disease expert, who had warned against reopening the country too quickly and stressed the unknown effects the coronavirus could have on children returning to school.

headline: Trump Administration Plans to Extend Virus Border Restrictions Indefinitely
text: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration is moving to extend its coronavirus border restrictions indefinitely, advancing the crackdown through broad public health authorities that have effectively sealed the United States to migrants seeking protection from persecution, according to officials and a draft of a public health order.

headline: Cycle of Arrests Leads Woman to Jail at a Dangerous Time
text: The coronavirus was probably already spreading through a jail in Montgomery, Ala., when Diamond Davis, a 27-year-old pregnant woman, was detained there on a recent Sunday.

headline: Cats Can Transmit the Coronavirus to Each Other, but They Probably Won’t Get Sick From It
text: Cats can infect each other with the novel coronavirus, but they may not have any symptoms, researchers reported on Wednesday in The New England Journal of Medicine.

headline: Leaves Before Paying the Check
text: THURSDAY PUZZLE — Crossword puzzles count as games in my book, as I often tell people who claim to be intimidated by the New York Times Crossword, and games are supposed to be fun. Solving a crossword with the same trepidation one might feel when sitting down to take an exam kind of misses the point.

headline: Quotation of the Day: The County Fair Is Canceled, a Blow to 4-H Kids and Their Protégés
text: “I talked to my goat. I told him to believe in himself.”

headline: Corrections: May 14, 2020
text: An article on Sunday about the end of past pandemics misstated the name of a prominent influenza doctor in 1918. He was Victor Vaughan, not William Vaughan.

headline: States Keep Failing Black People
text: The racially disproportionate effect of the Covid-19 crisis in this country and a recent rash of high-profile senseless killings of black people by the police and vigilantes may seem on their face unrelated.

headline: Michigan Barber Has Licenses Suspended After Defying Shutdown Orders
text: A Michigan barber who reopened his shop in defiance of Gov. Gretchen Whitmer’s orders had his business and professional licenses suspended on Wednesday, the latest step in his escalating battle with the state.

headline: Typhoon Vongfong Makes Landfall in the Philippines
text: MANILA — A typhoon packing winds of nearly 100 miles per hour made landfall in the eastern Philippines on Thursday after gathering strength across the Pacific Ocean, prompting evacuations and raising concerns that the nation’s most populous area may still lie in its path.

headline: TikTok Broke Privacy Promises, Children’s Groups Say
text: TikTok, the popular app for making and sharing short videos, has flouted an agreement it made with the Federal Trade Commission to protect the privacy of children on the service, a coalition of 20 children’s and consumer groups said on Thursday.

headline: Duterte’s Shutdown of TV Network Leaves Void Amid Coronavirus Crisis
text: MANILA — Through earthquakes and typhoons, floods and political turmoil, Fe Repalde knew she could count on one constant: Her tiny, flickering television was always tuned to ABS-CBN, one of the most influential networks in the Philippines.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday: ‘How to Get Away With Murder’ and ‘The Lodge’
text: HOW TO GET AWAY WITH MURDER 10 p.m. on ABC. After six seasons, the story of the criminal defense lawyer Annalise Keating (Viola Davis) comes to a close Thursday night, as “How to Get Away With Murder” airs its final episode. In the penultimate episode, a high-stakes trial began — with Annalise representing herself. How will it end? In a video promoting the finale, the show’s creator, Peter Nowalk, cautioned audiences not to expect justice. “I would be a big liar if I told a story where everyone got what they deserved,” he said. “That’s not what happens in life.”

headline: The Making of Marcus Rashford
text: The whole story can be distilled from the single conversation that started it all. A few weeks ago, Marcus Rashford was sitting at home with his family, watching the news pour in and the storm clouds gather.

headline: Word + Quiz: paucity
Two Climbers. Best Friends. Only One Ticket to the Olympics.
text: Mia Krampl, a professional rock climber from Slovenia, was in tears when she stepped onto the podium in third place at an Olympic qualifying competition in Toulouse, France, in December.

headline: Trump’s Low Approval Ratings Don’t Surprise Seth Meyers
text: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. We’re all stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Open and Shut
text: The map of the United States above was published in The Times on May 12. What can it tell you? How does it relate to or comment on society or current events? What is your opinion of its message?

headline: China’s ‘OK Boomer’: Generations Clash Over the Nation’s Future
text: China’s version of the “OK boomer” clash began when a famous middle-age actor praised the younger generation as if the country’s teenagers and 20-somethings were heaven-sent gifts.

headline: Ariane Mnouchkine: Half a Century Building Utopia
text: PARIS — As international theatermakers consider how to scale down their work for the era of social distancing, some companies are bound to struggle more than others. The revered French director Ariane Mnouchkine, 81, who is currently recovering from Covid-19, has already stated that she won’t consider requiring audience members and her performers to stand, or sit, farther apart than usual. In an interview with the magazine Télérama, she declared that would be “the opposite of joy.”

headline: Does It Matter What I Look Like When No One’s Watching?
text: I gathered over three million followers as a beauty guru. In quarantine, I’m wondering if I’ve been wearing makeup all wrong.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Lying in Your Dog’s Bed
text: Kelsey writes: My fiancé, Curt, and I live together along with our dog, Maggie. When we watch TV, Curt often lies in Maggie’s dog bed rather than sitting on our (large) couch. I think that’s gross. Maggie doesn’t like it, either. Please order Curt not to lounge in the dog bed.

headline: A Renter Tests His Budget in Connecticut. Which of These Homes Would You Choose?
text: An English transplant tours the amenity-filled rental developments in Stamford, looking for convenience and community. Here’s where he landed.

headline: The Title of Emma Straub’s New Novel Is Mocking Her
text: EX LIBRIS For many authors, especially those who are parents of small children, a book tour is the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow. Not only does it provide opportunities to discuss work undertaken over long periods of time, mostly in isolation, it also holds the promise of quiet hotel rooms and fat slabs of cheesecake delivered to your door.

headline: A 2-Year-Old TV Series’s Accidental Pandemic Commentary
text: Midway through the fourth episode of the mini-series “Waco,” two young children are peering out one of the bullet-shattered windows of Mount Carmel, the threadbare, plywood-walled compound in which the Branch Davidian sect has barricaded itself against an army of federal agents. A young man hustles them away from the glass, then looks out himself. On the perimeter of the property, an agent from an F.B.I. tactical unit is standing on top of a tank, mooning the compound.

headline: The Science Fiction Writer John Scalzi Readily Quits Reading
text: The author, whose new novel is “The Last Emperox,” says, “Life is short and there are many other books.”

headline: Poem: I Have Tried Hard to Have Appropriate Feelings
text: Susan Leslie Moore’s poem from “That Place Where You Opened Your Hands” instantly offers forthright presence: a personal voice making honest admissions. It’s a poem that opens hands and heart to a reader — no double talk or cryptic shadings. Including a turn on a familiar song line, a spatial obsession and that disquieting image of stranded polar bears, then the very original cure of being “kept in line” by something familiar outside the window, this poem suits our time of roller-coastering moods. Selected by Naomi Shihab Nye

headline: When Your Kid’s Heart Stops, There’s No Before
text: When Esmé’s body finally relaxes into mine, the clothing between us is damp. Heat always builds where we press against each other, but today it is exacerbated by her rising temperature and the rattle in her chest, courtesy of an adenovirus. It has been hours of this, holding my daughter’s restless body, careful not to disturb her as I shift my weight slightly, looking for some comfort in the awkward angle of the hospital bed.

headline: One Hospital Was Besieged by the Virus. Nearby Was ‘Plenty of Space.’
text: In late March, as the most dire public health crisis in a century swept across New York, sick people and those caring for them faced a hospital system that was less than the sum of its mighty parts.

headline: Check on an Extrovert Today
text: Introverts have ruled the social-media era. Before isolation became the norm, my feed was full of knowing jokes about how good it feels to cancel plans and ignore phone calls, how horrible it is to endure small talk.

headline: On Track for the Apocalypse, ‘Snowpiercer’ Comes to Television
text: Some ideas are just ahead of their time.

headline: Until My Disabled Son’s Needs Are Met, Can I Get a Genius Award?
text: I need a floor lift for my son. Well, I actually need a floor lift for me because, at 11 years old and over 100 pounds, my son has outgrown my strength and ability to safely help him from the floor mat where we do his physical therapy to his wheelchair.

headline: The Stresses of the Way We Work Now
text: Closed offices and restaurants. Shuttered stores and museums. Darkened schools and theaters.

headline: Does It Matter What I Look Like When No One’s Watching?
text: Daily makeup, nightly skin care, weekly manicures, monthly facials and quarterly hair appointments. It can be expensive — and exhausting — to be a woman. In the Video Op-Ed above, the beauty guru and YouTube creator Ingrid Nilsen challenges women to start asking whom we’re getting dolled up for — and stop apologizing for how we actually look.That’s not to say you should throw out your makeup bag because the world’s on fire. During the Great Depression, cosmetic sales actually shot up by 25 percent. In the 2001 recession, revenues from lipstick increased 11 percent in the United States. As the economy shrank in 2008, nail polish sales skyrocketed 65 percent. As Ms. Nilsen notes, a little indulgence may be the pick-me-up you need to get through tough times. But before you click to buy, it’s worth asking: Who is it actually for?

headline: A Phone, a Window and a Toaster Oven: How I Took Portraits From Miles Away
text: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: Campus Life in the Fall? A Test With No Clear Answer
text: SACRAMENTO — Fall will be quiet this year at San Diego State University. No big lecture classes. No parking lots packed with commuting students. No campus hubbub around Greek life, and perhaps no pep rallies for the Aztecs football team.

headline: André Leon Talley’s Tales From the Dark Side
text: There is a scene in “The September Issue,” the 2009 movie by R. J. Cutler about the making of the biggest Vogue of the year, that features the magazine’s then editor at large, André Leon Talley, huffing his way around a tennis court with a Louis Vuitton tennis racket case, Louis Vuitton tennis towel, Louis Vuitton beanie hat and Louis Vuitton sports bag.

headline: 50 Years Ago, Police Fired on Students at a Historically Black College
text: JACKSON, Miss. — In the 1960s, white motorists driving along John R. Lynch Street, which cut through the middle of the historically black campus of what was then called Jackson State College, would often taunt students along the way with racist epithets, throw objects at them and threaten to hit pedestrians.

headline: Why Are There Almost No Memorials to the Flu of 1918?
text: At Hope Cemetery in Barre, Vt., a five-ton granite bench sits on a triangle of grass. It is a mere five feet high and three feet deep, which seems modest in scale relative to the calamity it commemorates.

headline: A Study Said Covid Wasn’t That Deadly. The Right Seized It.
text: Last month, a group of Stanford University researchers released a remarkable study: Covid-19 infections in Santa Clara County, Calif., might well be 85 times higher than official estimates. The fatality rate for coronavirus might be as low as 0.12 percent, the researchers concluded, which would make Covid-19 only as deadly as the seasonal flu.

headline: How to Reopen America Safely
text: In late February, as data on the coronavirus pandemic continued to unfold, I started making calls to friends and family to prepare them. I told them to get ready to hunker down for three months. For many then, it was hard to believe that a virus we couldn’t much see evidence of, less understand, would require us to shut down our economy.

headline: The Sheer Number of School Districts Is Tilting the Playing Field
text: If we really want to balance school budgets in the wake of the coronavirus — and create more long-term equity in our public school system — we need to come to terms with the idea that we need far fewer than the 13,000 school districts that are currently in operation in the United States.

headline: What I Want the Woman Behind the Counter to Know
text: I wanted some noodles.

headline: Trump White House Changes Its Story on Michael Flynn
text: WASHINGTON — After announcing that the Justice Department was dropping the criminal case against Michael T. Flynn, the former national security adviser, Attorney General William P. Barr was presented with a crucial question: Was Mr. Flynn guilty of lying to the F.B.I. about the nature of phone calls he had with the Russian ambassador to the United States?

headline: Thousands Are Headed to Alaska’s Fishing Towns. So Is the Virus.
text: The people of Cordova, Alaska, had weathered the coronavirus pandemic with no cases and the comfort of isolation — a coastal town unreachable by road in a state with some of the fewest infections per capita in the country.

headline: Thursday’s Livestreaming Events: A 1985 Prince Concert, Elvis Costello, Sheryl Crow and More
text: Here are a few of the best events happening on Thursday and how to tune in (all times are Eastern).

headline: Hotels vs. Airbnb: Has Covid-19 Disrupted the Disrupter?
text: Airbnb, born in 2008, famously disrupted the hotel industry. It stole market share, put pressure on hotel rates, inspired the creation of affordable brands and saw hotels across the spectrum create restaurants, bars and lobbies that channeled the local vibe. Airbnb’s recent layoff of a quarter of its work force indicates the financial strain the company is under. Now the question is: Has Covid-19 disrupted the disrupter?

headline: Bill Barr’s Junk Justice
text: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:

headline: Praying Mantises: More Deadly Than We Knew
text: A praying mantis watches intently as a fly bobs by. In less than a blink, she’s snatched it up. When the tape is played back in slow motion, we see the mantis pause and calibrate, almost like an experienced baseball catcher who has realized she’s dealing with a knuckleball.

headline: A Black Hole’s Boomerangs
text: Astronomers have deciphered the dynamics of yet another great trick that monster black holes can play.

headline: As Unemployment Soars, Lawmakers Push to Cover Workers’ Wages
text: WASHINGTON — One of the most progressive lawmakers in the House and one of the most conservative in the Senate, staring down a pandemic-driven unemployment rate at its highest level since the Great Depression, have come to the same conclusion: It’s time for the federal government to cover workers’ salaries.

headline: Outside Egypt, Critics Speak Freely. Inside, Families Pay the Price.
text: CAIRO — When a popular Egyptian blogger shared gruesome video of a military officer severing the finger of an unidentified body and setting the body on fire, it was some of the most shocking footage to emerge from Sinai, where Egypt’s military has been battling Islamist militants in a hidden war.

headline: Quarantining With a Ghost? It’s Scary
text: It started with the front door.

headline: Meat Plant Closures Mean Pigs Are Gassed or Shot Instead
text: One Minnesota hog farmer sealed the cracks in his barn and piped carbon dioxide through the ventilation system. Another farmer has considered gassing his animals after loading them into a truck. And a third shot his pigs in the head with a gun. It took him all day.

headline: How Do You Maintain Dignity for the Dead in a Pandemic?
text: Nick Farenga stood amid the body bags in a refrigerated 18-wheel trailer at New York-Presbyterian Hospital/Columbia University Medical Center in Manhattan. “This is him,” a hospital worker said, pointing to a white body bag among the roughly 40 others lying on wooden platforms that resembled hastily constructed bunk beds. As a funeral director in the Bronx, Farenga has spent two months on the front lines of Covid-19, picking up dozens of bodies. Yet somehow, until that day in late April, he had escaped the pain of retrieving the body of someone he loved. Philip Foglia was Farenga’s former Little League coach. He and his brother, Sal, played baseball with Foglia’s sons; the families lived just blocks apart; their fathers were longtime friends.

headline: Coronavirus, Michael Flynn, Federal Reserve: Your Thursday Briefing
text: When the coronavirus lockdowns began almost two months ago, the outdoors seemed like a scary place. It was where you could get infected by a neighbor, jogger, public bench, doorknob or any number of other things. The better move, as a popular hashtag put it, was to #StayHome.

headline: The ‘American Way of Life’ Is Shaping Up to Be a Battleground
text: Chris Christie, a Trump supporter and a former New Jersey governor, pleaded with Americans on May 5 to risk disease and death by returning to work. “Everybody wants to save every life they can,” he said, but “we’ve got to let some of these folks get back to work.” Otherwise “we’re going to destroy the American way of life in these families.”

headline: Here’s How Wuhan Plans to Test All 11 Million of Its People for Coronavirus
text: Wuhan, the Chinese city where the coronavirus pandemic began, has announced an ambitious plan to test all of its 11 million residents for the virus in the coming days, a campaign that will be closely watched by governments elsewhere.

headline: On Politics: Stay at Home? States Can’t Agree
text: Vice President Mike Pence wore a mask as he arrived at the White House on Wednesday.

headline: ‘Fourteen’ Review: An Intertwined Friendship Unravels
text: The bittersweet character drama “Fourteen” examines a friendship that seems like it should last forever. Despite their differences, Mara (Tallie Medel) and Jo (Norma Kuhling) have been close since childhood. They’ve been friends long enough to have secrets from each other, and they’re close enough to know those secrets don’t really matter. The film around them is like their friendship — intellectual and loving, with a little too much left unsaid.

headline: ‘Graves Without a Name’ Review: An Impossible Quest in Cambodia
text: For years, people in the arts or in journalism have, in conversation, said of their vocation, “I didn’t choose it; it chose me.” At times this is an at least half-glib attempt to rationalize the often nonremunerative nature of their endeavors. But the truism gains some heft if looked at from a different angle.

headline: ‘The Wolf House’ Review: A Different Kind of Quarantine
text: Did you ever wonder what it might be like to be one of the three pigs of children’s story and animated cartoon fame? Is this a bad time to ask that question? Bear with me.

headline: ‘The Wrong Missy’ Review: Bad Romance
text: In “The Wrong Missy,” the twerpy bank executive Tim (David Spade) has just met his dream girl — and his nightmare. Trouble is, both women are named Melissa, and though he intended to text Melissa, the former Miss Maryland (Molly Sims), an invite to his company retreat in Hawaii (along with a selfie of his unmentionables), he’s accidentally made Melissa the motormouth (Lauren Lapkus) his plus-one, a feral lonely heart who forces a dog tranquilizer and a nonconsensual sex act on Tim before their plane has landed in paradise.

headline: India’s ‘Maximum City’ Engulfed by Coronavirus
text: The coronavirus problem that India had feared is becoming reality in Mumbai.

headline: Can You Break the Pull of a ZIP Code? Most Can’t
text: Our cities’ teachers on how children’s neighborhoods at birth shape their lives.

text: Want this in your inbox each morning? Sign up here.

headline: Five of New York’s 10 Regions Can Begin to Reopen on Friday
text: A five-county section of central New York that includes Syracuse has met the criteria necessary to begin reopening some businesses on Friday, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said on Thursday.

headline: Malaysia Drops Charges Against ‘Wolf of Wall Street’ Producer in 1MDB Case
text: BANGKOK — A Malaysian court on Thursday dismissed money laundering charges against the Hollywood producer Riza Aziz, a stepson of the country’s disgraced former prime minister Najib Razak, under an agreement in which he will return assets worth more than $107 million.

headline: ‘Rolling Shock’ as Job Losses Mount Even With Reopenings
text: Scattershot reopenings of retail stores, nail salons and restaurants around the country have not halted the flood of layoffs, with the government reporting Thursday that nearly three million people filed unemployment claims last week, bringing the two-month tally to more than 36 million.

headline: Amazon to the Rescue of the Fashion World!
text: Finally, Jeff Bezos is really in fashion.

headline: Adopting a Pet in California During a Pandemic
text: Good morning.

headline: ‘Blood and Money’ Review: A Deer Hunt Turns Cat-and-Mouse
text: Jim Reed (Tom Berenger), the primary, barely moving part of the backcountry thriller “Blood and Money,” is not a well man. A retired U.S. Marine whose alcoholism has him coughing blood and wheezing every few steps, Jim subsists on cigarettes, peanut-butter sandwiches and an array of medications. Not your typical action hero, you might think, and you’d be right; but that doesn’t stop Berenger and his director, John Barr, from spending the next hour and a half trying to prove otherwise.

headline: ‘Alice’ Review: The Escort Experience
text: In the French dramedy “Alice,” an overextended young mother wakes up one morning to find that her husband has disappeared, having secretly spent her entire inheritance on luxury escorts. Stuck with a mortgage, a furious Alice (Emilie Piponnier) goes to the escort agency frequented by her husband — a bright pink parlor where campy madams titter about their elite clientele. After a chat with a free-spirited escort, Lisa (Chloé Boreham), Alice gives the gig a shot herself.

headline: ‘Castle in the Ground’ Review: Dazed and Used
text: For Henry (Alex Wolff), the 19-year-old unfortunate at the heart of “Castle in the Ground,” crushing pills for his dying mother (Neve Campbell) is only the first step in a wearyingly familiar journey. And as he gradually transforms from grieving son to endangered opioid addict, his descent is so depressingly predictable that, for the viewer, sticking with this miserablist dependency drama could be quite the challenge.

headline: Rich Boss, Young Employee, Angry Wife: It Gets Twisted
text: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.

headline: The T List: Five Things We Recommend This Week
text: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we’re sharing things we’re eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. You can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.

headline: Appeals Court Allows Emoluments Suit Against Trump to Proceed
text: WASHINGTON — A federal appeals court in Virginia on Thursday revived a lawsuit accusing President Trump of violating the Constitution by profiting from his Washington hotel, a decision that will most likely lead the Justice Department to appeal to the Supreme Court to keep the plaintiffs from gathering evidence in the case.

headline: Should National Service Be Required for All Young Americans?
text: In Ghana, all young adults who graduate from an accredited university, college or trade school must complete one year of service in agriculture, health, education, local government or rural development.

headline: Months After Louisville Police Kill Woman in Her Home, Governor Calls for Review
text: Two months after Louisville police officers fatally shot a woman as they raided her home, Gov. Andy Beshear of Kentucky said on Wednesday that local, state and federal prosecutors should review the police investigation into the shooting.

headline: I Left My Husband Before the Pandemic. Can I Go Back to Him Now?
text: In February, I left my husband after being married for 18 years. We were teen parents who managed to keep it together, and our three amazing kids are almost grown. We were a heck of team, but we put each other through too much. Now, add the coronavirus! Sometimes, I just want to go home to the safety of my husband and have our kids under one roof again. I can’t be sure how I would be doing if this virus hadn’t come along. But if I go back, I’m afraid I won’t be able to leave him twice. What should I do?

headline: The Show’s Delayed, but They’re Still Keeping ‘Company’
text: The revival of “Company” was in previews and 10 days from opening when Broadway shut down. And opening night was meant to be especially special, timed to the 90th birthday of the musical’s composer Stephen Sondheim. Soon after, the show’s director, Marianne Elliott, returned to her husband and producing partner, Nick Sidi, and their daughter in London, while one of its stars, Patti LuPone, headed to the Connecticut home she shares with her husband, Matthew Johnston, and their son.

headline: A Cop Gets Away With Murder, Italian Style
text: A sleekly self-assured police chief pays an afternoon call on his slinky, kinky mistress. “How are you going to kill me today?” she purrs. Not only does he do so, but he also takes care to leave incriminating evidence everywhere around her place — daring his minions and superiors to find him guilty. (Is the killer an “idiot” or what, one investigator wonders.)

headline: G.O.P. Defiance of Pennsylvania’s Lockdown Has 2020 Implications
text: [Read our 2020 presidential election electoral college explainer.]

headline: An African Literary Festival for the Age of Coronavirus
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — For the novelist Maaza Mengiste, the coronavirus lockdowns and stay-at-home measures that have taken hold around the world have brought back the sense of exile she felt when she and her family fled Ethiopia in the 1970s.

headline: W.T.O. Chief Quits Suddenly, Adding to Global Turmoil
text: FRANKFURT — The head of the organization charged with bringing a semblance of order to international trade relations resigned unexpectedly Thursday, adding another element of uncertainty to commerce in the midst of the coronavirus pandemic and escalating trade conflicts.

headline: Jonathan Adewumi, Who Made Everyone Feel at Home, Dies at 57
text: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: My Kids Are Allergic to Video Chats
text: Since entering the world of pandemic parenting, I’ve found most of my kids’ behaviors to be reasonably predictable. For example, I knew my strong-willed 8-year-old would not love having me as his teacher; that my attached-at-my-hip 4-year-old would be especially clingy; and that they would both be asking me seemingly nonstop for a snack or to watch a TV show. This has all checked out. But there has been one behavior that has left me puzzled: their disinterest (and often downright disdain) for communicating with their friends online.

headline: The Drama Behind “Mad Max: Fury Road” Nearly Rivaled the Action Onscreen
text: Delays, fatigue, squabbles and harrowing stunts: Our reporter talked to the actors and director about the making of the action masterpiece.

headline: For Farmers of Wine Grapes, the Pandemic Sows Doubts
text: Ann Kraemer’s vineyard, Shake Ridge Ranch, covers 46 acres of rocky hillsides near Sutter Creek, in the Sierra Foothills of California.

headline: To Fight Waste and Hunger, Food Banks Start Cooking
text: BOYNTON BEACH, Fla. — The new kitchen was still under construction here at the Palm Beach County branch of Feeding South Florida, a food bank, when Chrissy Benoit walked through the warehouse in March. Fruits and vegetables had started arriving in unusually large amounts from nearby farms, which got her thinking about the cooking she would do when the kitchen was finished.

headline: As Coronavirus Overruns Russia, Doctors Are Dying on the Front Lines
text: MOSCOW — Dr. Rimma Kamalova says her hospital’s leadership ignored her warnings about an unexplained pneumonia outbreak back in March. She kept working.

headline: The New Museum Is Offering Strange Stories for Trying Times
text: It is no surprise that the storytelling series Maurizio Cattelan initiated doesn’t include “Goodnight Moon” or “The Tale of Peter Rabbit.” As an artist, Mr. Cattelan is known for skillfully subverting the expectations of his audience. Instead “Bedtime Stories,” a new digital offering from the New Museum, features cultural luminaries like David Byrne, Takashi Murakami and Elizabeth Peyton sharing selections from their favorite books, many of which are not standard nighttime fare for children or adults.

headline: G.D.P. Doesn’t Credit Social Distancing, but It Should
text: The United States is in a deep recession, but the official numbers are missing something big.

headline: Music, Theater and More to Experience at Home This Weekend
text: A stalwart of the traditional album cycle, Taylor Swift tends to juice her releases harder, and longer, than most artists. With the exception of her debut, she followed up each of her albums with a monthslong, intercontinental stadium tour. “Lover,” her seventh record, demanded an extra special touch: “open, fields, sunsets, + SUMMER,” Swift posted on Twitter. Shortly after delivering the album in August, she announced that she would once again be making the rounds with a string of European dates and so-called Lover Fests in the United States, all of which was to start in June.

headline: Now Streaming: French Movies for Every Niche
text: While various European film industries were decimated over the decades, France still stands strong, cranking out dozens of movies a year in every genre imaginable.

headline: Poor Americans Hit Hardest by Job Losses Amid Lockdowns, Fed Says
text: Households entered the coronavirus shutdown in precarious economic positions that have only worsened as workers are furloughed by the millions, and the challenges are especially acute for the poorest Americans, according to a Federal Reserve survey released Thursday.

headline: The Art Collections Are Real; the Owners Are Not
text: Episode 2 of “Mrs. America,” the new TV show dramatizing the battle over the Equal Rights Amendment, features a glamorous party at the Guggenheim Museum. It’s 1972, and Gloria Steinem is launching her new magazine, Ms. She mingles, dances and then talks shop with a fellow women’s movement leader, Bella Abzug. As the two walk up the museum’s ramp, artworks on the walls peek out behind them.

headline: Richard Burr Steps Back From Senate Panel as Phone Is Seized in Stock Sales Inquiry
text: WASHINGTON — Senator Richard M. Burr of North Carolina temporarily stepped down on Thursday as chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, a day after F.B.I. agents seized his cellphone as part of an investigation into whether he sold hundreds of thousands of dollars’ worth of stocks using nonpublic information about the coronavirus.

headline: 33 Teen-Chosen Quarantine Reads: The Results of Our Special April Challenge
text: When The Times announced in early April that all high school students in the United States could get three months of free digital access, we created a Special April Challenge to encourage students to first, explore NYTimes.com, and then, tell us what they read, watched or listened to and why. Over 200 teenagers participated, and our judges have chosen favorites, below.

headline: E.P.A. Opts Against Limits on Water Contaminant Tied to Fetal Damage
text: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration will not impose any limits on perchlorate, a toxic chemical compound that contaminates water and has been linked to fetal and infant brain damage, according to two Environmental Protection Agency staff members familiar with the decision.

headline: Quartz to Lay Off 80 Employees
text: Quartz, a business news site with offices around the world, is laying off nearly half its staff in a substantial restructuring after the economic fallout of the coronavirus pandemic drastically cut into its advertising revenue.

headline: The Joys of Fixing Your Own Stuff
text: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

headline: Jerzy Glowczewski, Polish Pilot in a Spitfire, Dies at 97
text: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: National Service: An Idea Whose Time Has Come
text: To the Editor:

headline: Fear, Trauma, Hope and Calm
text: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: Viewing Party! Let’s All Watch ‘What’s Up, Doc?’
text: We’re feeling loopy and a little loony tunes under lockdown, and bet you are, too. We want to run around in the great outdoors, chase after a pizza-delivery guy and maybe throw a cream pie in someone’s face, all of which happens in the madcap comedy “What’s Up, Doc?”

headline: 10 New Books We Recommend This Week
text: I participated this week in a virtual “Battle of the Books,” hosted by my local bookstore and moderated by James Mustich, the author of “1,000 Books to Read Before You Die.” The premise: Persuade the audience to vote for a book that Jim should have included on his list but didn’t. The format: Five contestants get four minutes each to make the case for a book of their choosing, from how-to (a cookbook, a feng shui decorating book) to fiction (José Saramago’s “Blindness,” Anton Myrer’s “Once an Eagle”) to — my pick — “The Journals of John Cheever,” which I consider his crowning achievement.

headline: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Easing Lockdowns
text: Note: This is our final graph for the 2019-20 school year. Please visit our archive to find dozens of other graphs you can use between now and September, when we will resume this feature. You can also sign up for our free weekly newsletter to make sure you don’t miss any of our new graphs.

headline: Canned Cocktails in Quarantine Make Mixing a One-Step Process
text: Jeff Wuslich, a founder of Cardinal Spirits in Bloomington, Ind., looked over a stack of more than 100 cases of canned cocktails at the distillery. There are three varieties: a Bramble Mule, made with vodka, raspberry juice, hibiscus and ginger; a Maui Mule, made with vodka, passion-fruit juice and ginger; and a vodka soda.

headline: Amazon’s Showdown in France Tests Its Ability to Sidestep Labor
text: PARIS — Workers at Amazon’s six mammoth French warehouses won some concessions from the company in late March: After hundreds of employees threatened to walk out unless the company better protected them from the coronavirus, the internet giant strengthened social distancing measures, provided masks and hand sanitizer and took employee temperatures.

headline: Trump’s Criticism of Fauci
text: To the Editor:

headline: On Second Viewing, First Impressions Don’t Always Hold
text: I hadn’t expected Simon Stephens’s “Sea Wall” to come to the rescue. Then suddenly there it was, saving me. A play that ran on Broadway just last summer, it also exists as a quietly gorgeous little film that feels like a gift from the past arriving exactly on time.

headline: How to Preserve and Store Your Hearty Greens
text: Whether you’re returning from an overambitious trip to the supermarket or organizing an unruly haul from your C.S.A. or farmers’ market, storing your seasonal bounty can be a challenge. Sturdy greens like kale, collard greens, Swiss chard, mustard greens and others can take up a lot of valuable real estate. You can store them in a fraction of the space — and prolong their life — by simply chilling them raw or cooked, or blanching and freezing them. Here’s how.

headline: This Atlas of Art and Memory Is a Wonder of the Modern World
text: For most of us, it’s natural to look at many pictures at the same time. We do it every day via internet searches and digital pinup boards — even refrigerator doors have become ad hoc photo albums.

headline: Italian Hostage’s Release Erupts Into Clashes Over Islam and Ransom
text: ROME — When word surfaced last weekend that a kidnapped 24-year-old Italian aid worker had been released after 18 months in captivity in Africa, Italians were overjoyed after weeks of relentlessly gloomy coronavirus-driven news.

headline: Laurie Anderson and Michael Stipe on Music, Art and New Chapters
text: At 72, no one would fault Laurie Anderson, the avant-garde multimedia icon — an inventor, performance artist, musician, writer, filmmaker, painter and more — for being nostalgic. She is best known for her 1981 surprise hit song, “O Superman,” a visionary tirade against American imperialism, built on looped vocal effects that seemed to predict the next three decades or so of pop music. In recent years, Anderson has been moonlighting as an archivist, shaping the legacy of her husband and collaborator, Lou Reed, who died in 2013. (His archives, which include letters, photographs and recordings, are now housed at the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts and are available to anyone with a library card.) But the experience of looking backward, immersed in another’s oeuvre, has only made Anderson’s own work more forward-looking.

headline: Richard Gilder, Donor to Parks, Museum and History, Dies at 87
text: Richard Gilder, a billionaire investor and benefactor who was instrumental in revitalizing two neglected exemplars of American democracy — the study of American history and Central Park — died on Tuesday at his home in Charlottesville, Va. He was 87.

headline: Martin Lovett, Last Living Member of the Amadeus Quartet, Dies at 93
text: The Amadeus, a string quartet of extraordinary longevity, set the gold standard in chamber music for four decades after World War II. Their style was a burnish on the Viennese tradition of smooth, lush string playing; they shone above a foundation provided by the solid, undemonstrative voice of their cellist, Martin Lovett.

headline: Will the Pandemic Make the West More Vulnerable to Wildfires?
text: The last thing we need right now is another risk to worry about. But across much of the American West, wildfires should be a big concern as summer approaches. This is especially true in Northern California, where the winter of 2019-20 was exceptionally dry and has set the stage for a potentially frightening wildfire season.

headline: What Churches Really Think About Opening Up
text: I pastor a church in Sonoma County, Calif., under what has been one of the strictest shelter-in-place orders in the country. We haven’t met for in-person worship services since March 8. We’ve spent the past two months with services, prayer times and Bible studies online. Gov. Gavin Newsom has announced that churches will not be meeting in large assemblies for some time. So with God’s help, prayer and encouragement from one another, we’re drawing upon deeper spiritual and relational resources as we seek to grow in patience, learn to wait and find new ways to minister to those in need.

headline: ‘I Wish I Could Do Something for You,’ My Doctor Said
text: The day before I got sick, I ran three miles, walked 10 more, then raced up the stairs to my fifth-floor apartment as always, slinging laundry with me as I went.

headline: Goodbye to One of the Most Complex Black Women on TV
text: It was the gasp heard in millions of living rooms around the country.

headline: Want to Try a Robert Bresson Film? Look to Clint Eastwood
text: Writing about the hard-edged American filmmaker Don Siegel (“Dirty Harry”), the critic Andrew Sarris once made an offhand observation about Siegel’s 1979 “Escape From Alcatraz,” starring Clint Eastwood. Siegel, he wrote, seemed “to have been inspired by Robert Bresson’s ‘A Man Escaped’ (1956).”

headline: How We Can Get the Next Phase of the Coronavirus Right
text: Heading into our pandemic summer, my biggest worry is that in the effort to get Americans to flatten the coronavirus curve, nobody prepared the country for what comes next.

headline: A Caddie’s Most Important Measure of Distance? Now It’s Six Feet
text: Missy Pederson is eager to get back to work caddying for the two-time major winner Brittany Lincicome on the L.P.G.A. Tour, which is scheduled to resume its season in July, five months after it was suspended because of the coronavirus crisis. “I’m chomping at the bit,” Pederson said on Tuesday in a telephone interview from her home in Minnesota.

headline: Yes, Kids Can Get Migraines. Here Are the Signs.
text: A couple of years ago, long before the novel coronavirus was a threat, my son started calling out to us soon after we tucked him in at night. Sometimes he would ask for an extra kiss, back rub or drink of water. All normal for a 5-year-old. But occasionally, he would report that his room looked funny. “Things that are close look far,” he would say. “And things that are far look close.”

headline: Travis McCready Concert Is Postponed, but Not Happily
text: The Arkansas authorities Thursday seized the liquor license of a concert hall planning what had been billed as the first major rock concert since the pandemic, forcing the promoters to delay the show, which was originally scheduled for Friday in Fort Smith.

headline: As Virus Ravages Budgets, States Cut and Borrow for Balance
text: In February, Ohio was running a $200 million budget surplus. Then the coronavirus pandemic struck, wiping out the surplus — and then some. Tax revenue plummeted and public health expenses skyrocketed.

text: J. Crew and Neiman Marcus were each facing a host of issues before the coronavirus pandemic forced them to close their stores and eventually file for bankruptcy, including trouble adjusting to the rise of e-commerce and a lack of connection with a new generation of shoppers.

headline: Review: ‘Snowpiercer’ on a New Track

It was just long enough for the film’s director, Bong Joon Ho, to give the show a publicity boost by winning multiple Oscars this year for “Parasite,” his latest violent allegory about the haves and have-nots.

headline: Coronavirus May Pose a New Risk to Younger Patients: Strokes

text: Clean the digital kiosks each time a customer orders. Place “closed” signs on certain tables to promote social-distancing. Scrub the bathrooms every half-hour.

headline: Talking Can Generate Coronavirus Droplets That Linger Up to 14 Minutes
text: Coughs or sneezes may not be the only way people transmit infectious pathogens like the novel coronavirus to one another. Talking can also launch thousands of droplets so small they can remain suspended in the air for eight to 14 minutes, according to a new study.

text: WASHINGTON — The whistle-blower who was ousted as the head of a federal medical research agency charged on Thursday that top Trump administration officials failed to heed his early warnings to stock up on masks and other supplies to combat the coronavirus, and that Americans died as a result.

text: On Tuesday, the U.S. government’s top experts warned that Covid-19 was by no means under control, and that premature easing of social distancing could have disastrous consequences. As far as I can tell, their view is shared by almost all epidemiologists.

headline: We Need Tuition-Free College. For Adults.

headline: U.S. Prison Population Remained Stable as Pandemic Grew

Biden Jr.’s mental state and paint the presumptive Democratic nominee as too friendly to the Chinese government.

headline: You Have to Let Go to Move On
text: My dating profile picture, a blurry, distant figure in a desert landscape, suggested a great deal about my ambivalence: I wanted, and I didn’t want. At 47, divorced for nearly two decades and with my daughters grown, I cherished my solitude, but sometimes when I heard the mice rustling in the attic, I thought of the newspaper story I had read about a man not far from where I lived who had been found dead in his flat, partly eaten by rats.

headline: U.S. and China Trade Coronavirus Accusations, Sparking Fears of a New Cold War
text: On May 1, a visibly relieved Matt Hancock announced that the British government had exceeded its target of 100,000 coronavirus tests a day. As health secretary, Mr. Hancock had set the goal after enduring intense criticism for the country’s lagging coronavirus testing program.

headline: Severe Tropical Storm Vongfong Takes Aim at Philippine Heartland

headline: What’s on TV Friday: ‘Barber Shop Chronicles’ and ‘Seberg’
text: BARBER SHOP CHRONICLES Stream on Nationaltheatre.org.uk. Barbershops are portrayed as communal spaces where patrons hang out and talk about politics, relationships and masculinity — and maybe also get their hair cut — in Inua Ellams’s “Barber Shop Chronicles,” a play that was a hit in London in 2017. The story bridges six barbershops in six cities, focusing on conversations in each shop over the course of a day. The fleet-footed script is based on recordings of conversations Ellams made in barbershops in Africa and London. “The men were just laughing whilst talking about really crazy issues,” Ellams said in an interview with The New York Times last year. “I had one rule: If a topic comes up three times in three different countries, then it has to go into the play.” This production, recorded during the show’s run at the National Theater in London, is streaming until late next week as part of a series of free programming being offered during the pandemic.

headline: Australia Is Returning to Normal. What Does That Mean?
text: Recently, as coronavirus restrictions began lifting, I met up with my good friend Sofia for a long walk along Sydney’s coastline. The weather had turned, finally, from a perennial summer to something chillier, but the ocean was full of the usual smattering of surfers and brave swimmers.

headline: Movie Theaters Are on the Brink. Can Wine and Cheese Save Them?

A mechanical orchestra pit rose and receded before screenings. The theater employed a male chorus, a ballet company and a chorus line called the Roxyettes.

headline: New in Paperback: ‘Walking on the Ceiling’ and ‘Good Husbandry’
text: WALKING ON THE CEILING,  by Aysegul Savas. (Riverhead, 224 pp., $16.) text: To the Editor:

headline: Rape, Torture, Murder, Beheadings — All in a Day’s Work for Marilyn Stasio
text: The Danish crime writer Jussi Adler-Olsen doesn’t fool around. If he wants to creep you out, he knows exactly how to do it. Take this passage from his latest Department Q novel, VICTIM 2117 (Dutton, 480 pp., $28), in which the villain torments a man named Assad by sending him a message about his abducted wife, Marwa. “It said that he made sure Marwa lost our third child,” Assad discloses, “and that he raped Marwa and my daughters every day, and that every time they gave birth, he immediately killed the child.” Has a certain sadistic ring to it, doesn’t it? That’s how we know we are indeed reading Adler-Olsen, whose style might best be described as literary brutalism.

headline: These Debuts Arrived at a Tough Time. They Deserve Your Attention.
text: MEMBERS ONLYBy Sameer Pandya351 pp. Houghton Mifflin Harcourt. $25.

headline: Weekly Health Quiz: Gyms, Elevators and Coronavirus
text: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: Anna Wintour Is Not the Star of André Leon Talley’s Memoir. He Is.
text: THE CHIFFON TRENCHESA MemoirBy André Leon Talley

headline: ‘Killing People in Fiction Was Fun’: Mysteries That Have Stood the Test of Time
text: I am, as we all are, stuck at home these days. Back in mid-March I assumed I would spend much of my time in lockdown reading — still and always my favorite activity, ideal for an indefinite period of mandatory solitude imposed by, say, a pandemic. This has not been the case. I’ve read fewer books over the past few weeks than I have over any comparable stretch that I can remember. Focus has evaporated. The cognitive load of living through the coronavirus has gone straight for my literary jugular.

headline: Finding Solace During This Great Global Pause
text: Is it OK to admit that I’m grateful for the isolation of the past few months? Because I am. I’m relishing this liminal space, this Great Global Pause.

headline: The Postal Service Is the Most American Thing We’ve Got
text: It would be difficult to think of a time when we have depended more on the United States Postal Service. With tens of millions of Americans quarantined in their homes, the steady delivery of checks, letters, food and medical supplies is a lifeline.

headline: Watching the Pandemic Steal Intimate Moments From Teenagers
text: On a day when my 17-year-old son can’t seem to summon the strength to wake up, I worry he’s coming down with the coronavirus or that he’s slipped into a deep depression. But he tells me that his partner, who is 19 and uses “they/them” pronouns, is moving into the nursing home where they work. He is listless from the losses of his deli job and the end of his senior year, angry that his partner is in such a compromising situation. Consistently exposed to Covid-19, his partner’s been forced to make the unfathomable choice of isolating in quarantine or exposing their household.

headline: Congress Doesn’t Need to Meet in Person
text: This month, in a long overdue change, the Senate finally started holding hybrid hearings, allowing both senators and health experts to appear via videoconferencing as well as in the Senate chamber. This occurred months after other public and private organizations all over the world had already made the transition to remote work. Just last week, the House majority leader introduced rule changes, passed on Friday, allowing the House to follow suit by permitting both remote hearings and remote voting.

headline: She Escaped Sex Work for College. Now the Virus Threatens Her New Life.
text: Last fall, toward the end of her first semester in college, Destiny Moura turned in a paper for an English composition class in which she described her introduction, at the age of 14, to “the life.’’ The “life’’ referred to the exploitation of girls by pimps, traffickers, manipulators.

headline: Miss Your Friends? Try Being a Teenager in Love
text: Gabby Rodriguez and Kai Laidhold ask to see each other every day. The answer from their parents is always the same: No.

headline: ‘Everybody Was Sick’: Inside an ICE Detention Center
text: Last month, Makalay Tarawally propped her 2-month-old in front of her phone so that his father could meet him for the first time, virtually. As a blood technician for a Covid-19 hospital unit, Ms. Tarawally knew how careful she needed to be.

headline: DeVos Funnels Coronavirus Relief Funds to Favored Private and Religious Schools
text: WASHINGTON — Education Secretary Betsy DeVos is using the $2 trillion coronavirus stabilization law to throw a lifeline to education sectors she has long championed, directing millions of federal dollars intended primarily for public schools and colleges to private and religious schools.

headline: These Large Carnivorous Lizards Are Right Where They Belong
text: You can’t accuse a monitor lizard of being a picky eater.

headline: Economists Want to Put Stimulus on Autopilot. Congress Has Other Ideas.
text: When there is an economic crisis, you want a government response that is scaled accordingly. But you don’t know in advance just how long a crisis will last or how severe it will be.

headline: This Summer, Consider Camping in Your Own Backyard
text: Our kids are going to have the weirdest memories of this time, and, ideally, some of them will be beautiful. Or at least comedic. This is where backyard camping comes in. Think s’mores, stars, the air mattress deflating with a cartoony hiss. Picture your children’s faces, fire-lit and, for just another minute, little. It could happen in farmland, suburbia or the Bronx — and it could be lovely. (And if you don’t have access to the outdoors, consider adapting these tips for the middle of your tiny apartment’s living room.)

headline: I Live in Sweden. I’m Not Panicking.
text: STOCKHOLM — It’s noon here, and from the window of my home office I can see my two daughters playing in the yard at their preschool across the street. I reach for my phone to text my best friend, a nurse who lives in Westport, Conn., to share some family trivia I just discovered. She has been hunkered down in her home with her husband and their two young daughters since March. She’s beginning to wonder what they will lose first — their jobs or their minds.

headline: Young Adults Take Refuge in Parents’ Empty Nests
text: Andrea Yoch loves her adult sons, but would also love to not live with them.

headline: How a Nurse Who Gives Last Rites Spends His Sundays
text: “No one is meant to see so much death that quickly,” said Yaakov Shereshevsky, an I.C.U. nurse at N.Y.U. Langone Health, where the coronavirus outbreak has taken a heavy toll. For a while, he said, eight floors — 34 beds on each floor — were devoted to Covid-19 patients, and they were at capacity. “At one point, we had 20- and 30-year-olds dying,” he said. “It was a horrible, brutal, helpless feeling. It felt like there was no light. Now it’s getting better.”

headline: Just Because You Can Afford to Leave the City Doesn’t Mean You Should
text: The image of cities as caldrons of contagion is a very old one. In the 19th century, rapid urbanization was accompanied by literal squalor and waves of often lethal communicable disease. Life expectancy declined during the Industrial Revolution as cities’ populations surged.

headline: Domestic Violence Calls Mount as Restrictions Linger: ‘No One Can Leave’
text: CHICAGO — The woman dialed the hotline from her car. Her partner was laid off from his job after the coronavirus outbreak hit the United States, she told the counselor, who listened from a basement call center in Chicago. He had become more tense and violent than ever. Please help.

headline: A 92-Year-Old Piano Teacher Won’t Let Students Miss Bach in the Pandemic
text: For more than 50 years, Cornelia Vertenstein, 92, has taught piano lessons from her home in Denver. Every week, through all those years, a parade of children came to her door, books in hand.

headline: What Black America Knows About Quarantine
text: On Feb. 23, a 25-year-old black man named Ahmaud Arbery left his home in Brunswick, Ga., to go for a Sunday afternoon run. As he entered a nearby subdivision, he was followed and later shot dead by a father and son while their neighbor recorded the incident on his phone.

headline: Trump, Biden and the Myth of ‘But 2016’
text: WASHINGTON — At first glance, there seems little in common between red-hat-wearing admirers of President Trump and Democratic activists still nursing PTSD from Hillary Clinton’s loss. Yet these political opposites share an overriding conviction, one they are apt to invoke any time the president’s re-election prospects are questioned:

headline: Obamagate Is a Fake Scandal. Rick Bright Described a Real One.
text: Recently people on the right have started pushing a ludicrous pseudo-scandal they’re calling Obamagate. It holds that investigations by Barack Obama’s administration into Russia’s attack on the 2016 U.S. presidential election were a form of illicit sabotage of Donald Trump and his team. The story doesn’t really make sense, which is why, when asked about Obamagate, President Trump couldn’t describe it. But at the heart of the conspiracy theory is “unmasking,” the routine practice by which national security officials find out the names of Americans who appear on intelligence intercepts of foreign actors. Trumpists have tried to turn this into a sinister and portentous term.

headline: With Go-Slow Approach, Republicans Risk Political Blowback on Pandemic Aid
text: WASHINGTON — More than eight weeks and almost $2.8 trillion federal dollars into an urgent response to the coronavirus pandemic, congressional Republicans and the Trump administration have made it clear that they are in no rush to engage with Democrats on another round of costly relief measures.

headline: Hospitals Knew How to Make Money. Then Coronavirus Happened.
text: When the top-ranked Mayo Clinic stopped all nonemergency medical care in late March, it began to lose millions of dollars a day.

headline: Beach Towns Ask: Will There Be Summer?
text: In summer resort towns across the United States, livelihoods for the year are built in the 15 weeks between Memorial Day and Labor Day. It is during those 15 weeks that tourists from around the country and the world arrive to bask on the beach and gather for festivals and weddings. And it is during those three months that tour operators, hoteliers, innkeepers, restaurant employees and others earn the bulk of their income.

headline: What to Buy to Create Your Own Backyard Campground
text: Being stuck at home doesn’t mean you can’t have an adventure, especially if you’re fortunate enough to have some outdoor space. Unlike the appeal of a long-distance hiking trip — which relies, of course, on seeing new landscapes — the magic of backyard camping, especially with children, is creating a fantasy in an otherwise familiar environment. It is a theater that we invent for ourselves. And like all good theater, no matter how minimal, the illusion is sustained in the details.

headline: Bringing ‘Normal People’ to Sexy, Soundtracked Life
text: Fans of Sally Rooney’s novel “Normal People” are devoted types. They tend to hold the book’s central mismatched-but-also-kind-of-perfect-together couple, Marianne and Connell, close to their hearts. So adapting the book for TV came with risks. “It was a big leap of faith,” Rooney told The Hollywood Reporter earlier this year about casting the show, “that we were going to find people who would just get it, and would know exactly how to communicate that friction between the inner life and the outer world.” Daisy Edgar-Jones and Paul Mescal have received widespread acclaim for their performances in the 12-part series on Hulu. Some of the praise for the show came from James Poniewozik, The Times’s chief television critic, who called it a “gorgeous, melancholy series” starring leads who “have so much chemistry you may need lab goggles.” Poniewozik recently joined The Times’s three book critics — Dwight Garner, Parul Sehgal and Jennifer Szalai — for a discussion I moderated about the show, the novel, the art of adaptation and more. — John Williams, Daily Books Editor

headline: ‘We’re Just Horrified’: Why a Springsteen Sideman Took On Nursing Homes
text: When the coronavirus outbreak was only manifesting itself in horrifying headlines from Italy and China, Nils Lofgren, the guitarist for Bruce Springsteen’s E Street Band, and his wife, Amy, moved her mother into Brookdale Senior Living, a well-regarded long term care facility in Florham Park, N.J.

headline: Livestreams to Watch: A Star-Studded Graduation Event, and Katy Perry Performs
text: Here are a few of the best events happening Friday through Wednesday and how to tune in (all times are Eastern).

headline: 9 Top (and Stubborn) Design Trends
text: Being confined to my home for the last two months has led me to think deeply about subway tile. It neatly covers my kitchen backsplash, and very possibly yours, but do its origins really lie in the subways? Why would that environment be anyone’s inspiration? And why is it so crazily popular now?

headline: America’s Cities Could House Everyone if They Chose To
text: Tonight, more than half a million Americans will sleep in public places because they lack private spaces. They will huddle in crowded New York City shelters, or pitch tents under highways in Washington, D.C., or curl up in the doorways of San Francisco office towers, or dig holes in the high desert of northern Los Angeles County.

headline: Lobby Heroes of the Lockdown
text: When Genc Rrahmani was growing up in Kosovo, he would fantasize about his future life in New York City. “I was thinking that the U.S. has a lot of money,” Genc said recently. “That I would work hard and start a business, and have a beautiful future with a beautiful family.”

headline: Trump Is Following in Herbert Hoover’s Footsteps
text: Additional economic assistance is the only thing that can keep the U.S. economy from falling into a second Great Depression, and with interest rates near zero, the government has all the fiscal capacity it needs to borrow the trillions necessary to relieve the pain. But Congress, or rather congressional Republicans, won’t budge. After backing the $2 trillion CARES Act in March, they believe they’ve done enough for now.

headline: Examining the Meaning of ‘Mrs.’
text: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: What Home Means to the Homeless
text: What makes a home? Is it the materials we use to make the structure or the things we put in it? Is it the people who occupy the space or the memories we accumulate there? The question has vastly different meanings for people who have experienced homelessness, one of the most shameful manifestations of inequality in America.

headline: Graduation Ceremonies in Quarantine
text: The day the governor of Rhode Island announced that schools would remain closed for the rest of the school year, Dan Freedman rallied his high school classmates to gather for an impromptu car parade on campus.

headline: Sweden Stayed Open. A Deadly Month Shows the Risks.
text: While Sweden has avoided the worst outbreaks in Italy, Spain and Britain, it has also seen an extraordinary increase in deaths, mortality data shows.

headline: The 100-Year-Old Who Raised $40 Million for U.K. Health Workers
text: MARSTON MORETAINE, England — Hannah Ingram-Moore always knew her dad was a good story.

headline: Reopening, Warily
text: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

headline: How (and Why) to Use Native Plants
text: In recent years, the demand for pollinator plants has surged. But most of us don’t have room for a meadow.

headline: A Very Small Family Gathering Will Do This Time
text: Michael Cicoria is not the type to automatically pull out chairs and hold doors. But he will admit that when it comes to chivalry, he has his moments.

headline: Coronavirus, Jobs, Richard Burr: Your Friday Briefing
text: Almost every country across Europe and North America has put in place some kind of lockdown. But not every country has experienced the sharp increase in unemployment that the United States has.

headline: Trump’s Ratings on the Virus Are Sagging. Why Isn’t Biden Surging?
text: It’s been a little over a month since Joseph R. Biden Jr. became the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee, and what a month it’s been.

headline: Private Equity Didn’t Help
text: Good morning. (Was this email forwarded to you? Sign up here.)

headline: Some Northeast Beaches Set to Open Next Week, but Not in N.Y.C.
text: [This briefing has ended. For the latest updates on the coronavirus outbreak in the New York area, read Saturday’s live coverage.]

headline: A Jazz Pianist Flips Bach Upside-Down
text: In March, the jazz pianist and composer Dan Tepfer found himself confined to his apartment in Brooklyn with all his bookings canceled for the foreseeable future, like musicians everywhere. So he decided to work seriously on an idea he had long been toying with.

headline: How Is Your Family Dividing Responsibilities During the Quarantine?
text: How has the coronavirus affected family life and dynamics in your home? Have roles dramatically changed during social-distancing restrictions?

headline: Film Club: ‘Are Ice Cream Trucks Essential? In These N.Y.C. Neighborhoods, They Are’
text: Note: This is our final Film Club for the 2019-20 school year. Please visit our archive to find dozens of other short films you can use between now and September, when we will resume this feature. You can also sign up for our free weekly newsletter to make sure you don’t miss any of our new films.

headline: When Shoppers Venture Out, What Will Be Left?
text: The coronavirus pandemic dealt another crushing blow to retailers in April. Now the question is what the sector will look like as the economy reopens — and how much permanent damage has been inflicted.

headline: 11 of Our Best Weekend Reads
text: Welcome to the weekend. Is the world around you reopening? It’s strange to hear a constant hum of traffic out my window, to see people carrying takeaway coffee cups, to see kids at the park. It shouldn’t be strange, people doing what they do, but right now it is. I am trying to be patient with myself as life uncoils itself back out into the world. I hope you are, too, and that whatever you’re doing, you take some time to read some amazing journalism.

headline: ‘The Blacklist’ Draws Up a Novel End to Its Season
text: In mid-March, when the coronavirus pandemic shut New York City down, television production came to a sudden halt, sabotaging whole seasons for some shows and postponing season finales for others. But NBC’s “The Blacklist,” which follows James Spader’s Raymond “Red” Reddington as he helps the F.B.I. bring down the world’s most nefarious criminals, soldiered on.

headline: One Side Effect of the Virus: Free Credit Reports Each Week
text: The economic turmoil caused by the coronavirus has prompted a helpful — if temporary — change in the window that Americans have into their credit files.

headline: Why So Many Filipino Californians Are on the Front Lines
text: Good morning.

headline: Why Sofas? These Books Explain the Joys and Mysteries of the Home
text: Have you ever wondered how forks ended up with four tines, where to store off-season clothes when you live in a small space, or why there’s green felt on pool tables? These books have answers.

headline: Oprah to Class of 2020: ‘What Will Your Essential Service Be?’
text: Hugging friends? Nope. Class photos? Afraid not. Instead, in place of the usual pomp and circumstance, Oprah Winfrey on Friday asked America’s graduates — the “pandemic class,” she called them — to consider what their “essential service” in this world would be.

headline: U.S. Delivers Another Blow to Huawei With New Tech Restrictions
text: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration issued a new rule Friday that will bar Huawei and its suppliers from using American technology and software, a significant escalation in the White House’s battle with the Chinese telecom giant and one that is likely to inflame tensions with Beijing.

headline: Six Swipes for a Better Night’s Sleep
text: Our daily patterns are all off, so our circadian rhythms are too. These tips will help.

headline: Within a Week, They Fell in Love
text: Clare Goslant was in search of an affordable place to live in Washington, when she took time off between her junior and senior years at Harvard for an internship with the World Wildlife Fund.

headline: In Jerusalem, Ramadan Restrictions Last Seen During the Crusades Return
text: JERUSALEM — The last time Muslim worshipers were kept out of the Aqsa Mosque compound throughout the entire month of Ramadan was when crusaders controlled Jerusalem in the Middle Ages.

headline: Women Face Dilemma in a War Zone: Risk the Blasts or Sexual Assault
text: NEELUM VALLEY, Kashmir — There is another lockdown underway, forced by falling artillery shells rather than invading viruses. This one also requires frightening choices between bad options.

headline: Paintings that Demolish the Myths of What a Home Should Be
text: Were someone to ask me for an image that clearly represents nostalgia — the definition drawn from Greek of the feeling of ache or pain associated with homecoming — I might point them to the work of the artist Naomi Safran-Hon who makes paintings of (among other things) lost and abandoned homes.

headline: The Mrs. Files
text: The Mrs. Files looks at history through a contemporary lens to see what the honorific “Mrs.” means to women and their identity.

headline: Trump Vows Vaccine by End of Year, and Mobilizes Military to Help
text: President Trump doubled down on Friday on his promise to have a coronavirus vaccine available by the end of this year, betting that he can rally the pharmaceutical industry and the government to have one available to nearly all Americans at a speed never before accomplished.
